metadata.title: Install Updates, Patches and Additional Security Software (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Periodically patches are released for included software either due to security flaws or to include additional functionality. The zypper tool provides automatic package management functionality through terminal while YaST provides management in a graphical environment.

criteria.comment: Install Updates, Patches and Additional Security Software (Not Scored)

criterion.comment: Install Updates, Patches and Additional Security Software (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Create Separate Partition for /tmp (Scored)
metadata.description: The /tmp directory is a world-writable directory used for temporary storage by all users and some applications.

metadata.title: Set nodev option for /tmp Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: The nodev mount option specifies that the filesystem cannot contain special devices.

metadata.title: Set nosuid option for /tmp Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: The nosuid mount option specifies that the filesystem cannot contain set userid files.

metadata.title: Set noexec option for /tmp Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: The noexec mount option specifies that the filesystem cannot contain executable binaries.

metadata.title: Create Separate Partition for /var (Scored)
metadata.description: The /var directory is used by daemons and other system services to temporarily store dynamic data. Some directories created by these processes may be world-writable.

metadata.title: Bind Mount the /var/tmp directory to /tmp (Scored)
metadata.description: The /var/tmp directory is normally a standalone directory in the /var file system. Binding /var/tmp to /tmp establishes an unbreakable link to /tmp that cannot be removed (even by the root user). It also allows /var/tmp to inherit the same mount options that /tmp owns, allowing /var/tmp to be protected in the same /tmp is protected. It will also prevent /var from filling up with temporary files as the contents of /var/tmp will actually reside in the file system containing /tmp.

metadata.title: Create Separate Partition for /var/log (Scored)
metadata.description: The /var/log directory is used by system services to store log data .

metadata.title: Create Separate Partition for /var/log/audit (Scored)
metadata.description: The auditing daemon, auditd, stores log data in the /var/log/audit directory.

metadata.title: Create Separate Partition for /home (Scored)
metadata.description: The /home directory is used to support disk storage needs of local users.

metadata.title: Add nodev Option to /home (Scored)
metadata.description: When set on a file system, this option prevents character and block special devices from being defined, or if they exist, from being used as character and block special devices.

metadata.title: Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Set nodev on removable media to prevent character and block special devices that are present on the removable be treated as these device files.

criteria.comment: Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

criterion.comment: Add nodev Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Set noexec on removable media to prevent programs from executing from the removable media.

criteria.comment: Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

criterion.comment: Add noexec Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Set nosuid on removable media to prevent setuid and setgid executable files that are on that media from being executed as setuid and setgid.

criteria.comment: Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

criterion.comment: Add nosuid Option to Removable Media Partitions (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Add nodev Option to /dev/shm Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: The nodev mount option specifies that the /dev/shm (temporary filesystem stored in memory) cannot contain block or character special devices.

metadata.title: Add nosuid Option to /dev/shm Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: The nosuid mount option specifies that the /dev/shm (temporary filesystem stored in memory) will not execute setuid and setgid on executable programs as such, but rather execute them with the uid and gid of the user executing the program.

metadata.title: Add noexec Option to /dev/shm Partition (Scored)
metadata.description: Set noexec on the shared memory partition to prevent programs from executing from there.

metadata.title: Set Sticky Bit on All World-Writable Directories (Scored)
metadata.description: Setting the sticky bit on world writable directories prevents users from deleting or renaming files in that directory that are not owned by them.

criteria.comment: Set Sticky Bit on All World-Writable Directories (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set Sticky Bit on All World-Writable Directories (Scored)

metadata.title: Disable Mounting of udf Filesystems (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The udf filesystem type is the universal disk format used to implement ISO/IEC 13346 and ECMA-167 specifications. This is an open vendor filesystem type for data storage on a broad range of media. This filesystem type is necessary to support writing DVDs and newer optical disc formats.

criteria.comment: Disable Mounting of udf Filesystems (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Disable Automounting (Scored)
metadata.description: autofs allows automatic mounting of devices, typically including CD/DVDs and USB drives.

metadata.title: Set User/Group Owner on bootloader config (Scored)
metadata.description: Set the owner and group of your boot loaders config file to the root user. Suse default to GRUB stored at /boot/grub/menu.lst. Packages are available for LILO but it is not recommended.

metadata.title: Set Permissions on bootloader config (Scored)
metadata.description: Set permission on the your boot loaders config file to read and write for root only.

metadata.title: Set Boot Loader Password (Scored)
metadata.description: Setting the boot loader password will require that the anyone rebooting the system must enter a password before being able to set command line boot parameters

metadata.title: Require Authentication for Single-User Mode (Scored)
metadata.description: Since /etc/inittab determines what run state the system is in, setting the entry in /etc/inittab will force single user authentication.

metadata.title: Disable Interactive Boot (Scored)
metadata.description: The PROMPT_FOR_CONFIRM option provides console users the ability to interactively boot the system and select which services to start on boot .

metadata.title: Restrict Core Dumps (Scored)
metadata.description: A core dump is the memory of an executable program. It is generally used to determine why a program aborted. It can also be used to glean confidential information from a core file. The system provides the ability to set a soft limit for core dumps, but this can be overridden by the user.

metadata.title: Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Recent processors in the x86 family support the ability to prevent code execution on a per memory page basis. Generically and on AMD processors, this ability is called No Execute (NX), while on Intel processors it is called Execute Disable (XD). This ability can help prevent exploitation of buffer overflow vulnerabilities and should be activated whenever possible. Extra steps must be taken to ensure that this protection is enabled, particularly on 32-bit x86 systems. Other processors, such as Itanium and POWER, have included such support since inception and the standard kernel for those platforms supports the feature.

criteria.comment: Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems (Not Scored)

criterion.comment: Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems (Not Scored)
Enable XD/NX Support on 32-bit x86 Systems (Not Scored)

metadata.description: Set the system flag to force randomized virtual memory region placement.

criteria.comment: Enable Randomized Virtual Memory Region Placement (Scored)

criterion.comment: Enable Randomized Virtual Memory Region Placement (Scored)

metadata.title: Disable Prelink (Scored)
metadata.description: The prelinking feature changes binaries in an attempt to decrease their startup time.

metadata.title: Activate AppArmor (Scored)
metadata.description: AppArmor provides a Mandatory Access Control (MAC) system that greatly augments the default Discretionary Access Control (DAC) model.

metadata.title: Ensure NIS Server is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: The Network Information Service (NIS) (formally known as Yellow Pages) is a client-server directory service protocol for distributing system configuration files. The NIS server is a collection of programs that allow for the distribution of configuration files.

criteria.comment: Ensure NIS Server is not enabled (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure NIS Server is not enabled (Scored)

The NIS client (ypbind) was used to bind a machine to an NIS server and receive the distributed configuration files.

metadata.title: Ensure telnet server is not enabled (Scored)

criteria.comment: Ensure telnet server is not enabled (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure telnet server is not enabled (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure tftp-server is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) is a simple file transfer protocol, typically used to automatically transfer configuration or boot machines from a boot server. The packages tftp and atftp are both used to define and support a TFTP server.

metadata.title: Ensure xinetd is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: The eXtended InterNET Daemon (xinetd) is an open source super daemon that replaced the original inetd daemon. The xinetd daemon listens for well known services and dispatches the appropriate daemon to properly respond to service requests.

metadata.title: Ensure chargen-udp is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: chargen-udp is a network service that responds with 0 to 512 ASCII characters for each datagram it receives. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure chargen is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: chargen is a network service that responds with 0 to 512 ASCII characters for each connection it receives. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure daytime-udp is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: daytime-udp is a network service that responds with the server's current date and time. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure daytime is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: daytime is a network service that responds with the server's current date and time. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure echo-udp is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: echo-udp is a network service that responds to clients with the data sent to it by the client. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure echo is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: echo is a network service that responds to clients with the data sent to it by the client. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure discard-udp is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: discard-udp is a network service that simply discards all data it receives. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure discard is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: discard is a network service that simply discards all data it receives. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure time-udp is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: time-udp is a network service that responds with the server's current date and time as a 32 bit integer. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure time is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: time is a network service that responds with the server's current date and time as a 32 bit integer. This service is intended for debugging and testing purposes. It is recommended that this service be disabled.

metadata.title: Ensure X Windows is not installed (Scored)
metadata.description: The X Windows system provides a Graphical User Interface (GUI) where users can have multiple windows in which to run programs and various add on. The X Windows system is typically used on desktops where users login, but not on servers where users typically do not login.

criteria.comment: Ensure X Windows is not installed (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure X Windows is not installed (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure Avahi Server is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: Avahi is a free zeroconf implementation, including a system for multicast DNS/DNS-SD service discovery. Avahi allows programs to publish and discover services and hosts running on a local network with no specific configuration. For example, a user can plug a computer into a network and Avahi automatically finds printers to print to, files to look at and people to talk to, as well as network services running on the machine.

criteria.comment: Ensure Avahi Server is not enabled (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure Avahi Server is not enabled (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure print server is not enabled (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Common Unix Print System (CUPS) provides the ability to print to both local and network printers. A system running CUPS can also accept print jobs from remote systems and print them to local printers. It also provides a web based remote administration capability.

metadata.description: The Network Time Protocol (NTP) is designed to synchronize system clocks across a variety of systems and use a source that is highly accurate. More information on NTP can be found at http://www.ntp.org. NTP can be configured to be a client and/or a server.

metadata.title: Ensure LDAP is not enabled (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) was introduced as a replacement for NIS/YP. It is a service that provides a method for looking up information from a central database.

metadata.description: The Domain Name System (DNS) is a hierarchical naming system that maps names to IP addresses for computers, services and other resources connected to a network.

metadata.description: The Samba daemon allows system administrators to configure their Linux systems to share file systems and directories with Windows desktops. Samba will advertise the file systems and directories via the Small Message Block (SMB) protocol. Windows desktop users will be able to mount these directories and file systems as letter drives on their systems.

metadata.description: The Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) server is used to listen for SNMP commands from an SNMP management system, execute the commands or collect the information and then send results back to the requesting system.

metadata.title: Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode (Scored)
metadata.description: Mail Transfer Agents (MTA), such as sendmail and Postfix, are used to listen for incoming mail and transfer the messages to the appropriate user or mail server. If the system is not intended to be a mail server, it is recommended that the MTA be configured to only process local mail.

criteria.comment: Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode (Scored)

criterion.comment: Configure Mail Transfer Agent for Local-Only Mode (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure rsync service is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: The rsyncd service can be used to synchronize files between systems over network links.

criteria.comment: Ensure rsync service is not enabled (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure rsync service is not enabled (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure Biosdevname is not enabled (Scored)
metadata.description: YaST2 automatically installs biosdevname, if YaST2 auto-detects hardware compatible with biosdevname. biosdevname uses three methods to determine NIC names: 1. PCI firmware spec.3.1. 2. smbios (matches # after "em" to OEM # printed on board or housing). 3. PCI IRQ Routing Table (uses # of NIC position in the device history). If the BIOS does not support biosdevname, no NICs' are re-named.

metadata.title: Disable IP Forwarding (Scored)
metadata.description: The net.ipv4.ip_forward flag is used to tell the server whether it can forward packets or not. If the server is not to be used as a router, set the flag to 0.

metadata.title: Disable Send Packet Redirects (Scored)
metadata.description: ICMP Redirects are used to send routing information to other hosts. As a host itself does not act as a router (in a host only configuration), there is no need to send redirects.

metadata.title: Disable Source Routed Packet Acceptance (Scored)
metadata.description: In networking, source routing allows a sender to partially or fully specify the route packets take through a network. In contrast, non-source routed packets travel a path determined by routers in the network. In some cases, systems may not be routable or reachable from some locations (e.g. private addresses vs. Internet routable), and so source routed packets would need to be used.

metadata.title: Disable ICMP Redirect Acceptance (Scored)
metadata.description: ICMP redirect messages are packets that convey routing information and tell your host (acting as a router) to send packets via an alternate path. It is a way of allowing an outside routing device to update your system routing tables. By setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects to 0, the system will not accept any ICMP redirect messages, and therefore, won't allow outsiders to update the system's routing tables.

metadata.title: Disable Secure ICMP Redirect Acceptance (Scored)
metadata.description: Secure ICMP redirects are the same as ICMP redirects, except they come from gateways listed on the default gateway list. It is assumed that these gateways are known to your system, and that they are likely to be secure.

metadata.title: Log Suspicious Packets (Scored)
metadata.description: When enabled, this feature logs packets with un-routable source addresses to the kernel log.

metadata.title: Enable Ignore Broadcast Requests (Scored)
metadata.description: Setting net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts to 1 will cause the system to ignore all ICMP echo and timestamp requests to broadcast and multicast addresses.

metadata.title: Enable Bad Error Message Protection (Scored)
metadata.description: Setting icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses to 1 prevents the the kernel from logging bogus responses (RFC-1122 non-compliant) from broadcast reframes, keeping file systems from filling up with useless log messages.

metadata.title: Enable RFC-recommended Source Route Validation (Scored)
metadata.description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter and net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter to 1 forces the Linux kernel to utilize reverse path filtering on a received packet to determine if the packet was valid. Essentially, with reverse path filtering, if the return packet does not go out the same interface that the corresponding source packet came from, the packet is dropped (and logged if log_martians is set).

metadata.title: Enable TCP SYN Cookies (Scored)
metadata.description: When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks in. SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the server to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

metadata.title: Disable IPv6 Router Advertisements (Not Scored)
metadata.description: When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks in. SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the server to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

metadata.title: Disable IPv6 Redirect Acceptance (Not Scored)
metadata.description: When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks in. SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the server to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

metadata.title: Disable IPv6 (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Although IPv6 has many advantages over IPv4, few organizations have implemented IPv6.

metadata.title: Install TCP Wrappers (Scored)
metadata.description: TCP Wrappers provides a simple access list and standardized logging method for services capable of supporting it. In the past, services that were called from inetd and xinetd supported the use of tcp wrappers. As inetd and xinetd have been falling in disuse, any service that can support tcp wrappers will have the libwrap.so library attached to it.

metadata.title: Verify Permissions on /etc/hosts.allow (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/hosts.allow file contains networking information that is used by many applications and therefore must be readable for these applications to operate.

metadata.title: Create /etc/hosts.deny (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/hosts.deny file specifies which IP addresses are not permitted to connect to the host. It is intended to be used in conjunction with the /etc/hosts.allow file.

metadata.title: Verify Permissions on /etc/hosts.deny (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/hosts.deny file contains network information that is used by many system applications and therefore must be readable for these applications to operate.

metadata.title: Disable DCCP (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) is a transport layer protocol that supports streaming media and telephony. DCCP provides a way to gain access to congestion control, without having to do it at the application layer, but does not provide in-sequence delivery.

metadata.title: Disable SCTP (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol used to support message oriented communication, with several streams of messages in one connection. It serves a similar function as TCP and UDP, incorporating features of both. It is message-oriented like UDP, and ensures reliable in-sequence transport of messages with congestion control like TCP.

metadata.title: Disable RDS (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol is a transport layer protocol designed to provide low-latency, high-bandwidth communications between cluster nodes. It was developed by the Oracle Corporation.

metadata.title: Disable TIPC (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol is designed to provide communication between cluster nodes.

metadata.title: SuSEfirewall2 is active (Scored)
metadata.description: SuSEfirewall2 is a script that generates IPtables rules from configuration stored in the /etc/sysconfig/SuSEfirewall2 file. IPtables is an application that allows a system administrator to configure the IPv4 tables, chains and rules provided by the Linux kernel firewall.

metadata.title: Limit access to trusted networks (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Use the standard system firewall configuration facility (SuSEfirewall2) to define networks to be trusted.

criteria.comment: Limit access to trusted networks (Not Scored)

metadata.title: Configure Audit Log Storage Size (Not Scored)

metadata.description: Capture events where the system date and/or time has been modified. The parameters in this section are set to determine if the adjtimex (tune kernel clock), settimeofday (Set time, using timeval and timezone structures) stime (using seconds since 1/1/1970) or clock_settime (allows for the setting of several internal clocks and timers) system calls have been executed and always write an audit record to the /var/log/audit.log file upon exit, tagging the records with the identifier "time-change"

The parameters in this section will watch the files to see if they have been opened for write or have had attribute changes (e.g. permissions) and tag them with the identifier "identity" in the audit log file.

The below parameters monitor the sethostname (set the systems host name) or setdomainname (set the systems domainname) system calls, and write an audit event on system call exit. The other parameters monitor the /etc/issue and /etc/issue.net files (messages displayed pre-login), /etc/hosts (file containing host names and associated IP addresses) and /etc/sysconfig/network (directory containing network interface scripts and configurations) files.

metadata.title: Record Events That Modify the System's Mandatory Access Controls (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor SELinux mandatory access controls. The parameters below monitor any write access (potential additional, deletion or modification of files in the directory) or attribute changes to the /etc/selinux directory.

criteria.comment: Record Events That Modify the System's Mandatory Access Controls (Scored)

criterion.comment: Record Events That Modify the System's Mandatory Access Controls (Scored)

metadata.title: Collect Login and Logout Events (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor login and logout events. The parameters below track changes to files associated with login/logout events. The file /var/log/faillog tracks failed events from login. The file /var/log/lastlog maintain records of the last time a user successfully logged in. The file /var/log/btmp keeps track of failed login attempts and can be read by entering the command /usr/bin/last -f /var/log/btmp. All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "logins."

metadata.title: Collect Session Initiation Information (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor session initiation events. The parameters in this section track changes to the files associated with session events. The file /var/run/utmp file tracks all currently logged in users. The /var/log/wtmp file tracks logins, logouts, shutdown and reboot events. All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "session."

metadata.title: Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor changes to file permissions, attributes, ownership and group. The parameters in this section track changes for system calls that affect file permissions and attributes. The chmod, fchmod and fchmodat system calls affect the permissions associated with a file. The chown, fchown, fchownat and lchown system calls affect owner and group attributes on a file. The setxattr, lsetxattr, fsetxattr (set extended file attributes) and removexattr, lremovexattr, fremovexattr (remove extended file attributes) control extended file attributes. In all cases, an audit record will only be written for non-system userids (auid >= 500) and will ignore Daemon events (auid = 4294967295). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "perm_mod."

criteria.comment: Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)

criterion.comment: Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)
Collect Discretionary Access Control Permission Modification Events (Scored)

metadata.title: Collect Unsuccessful Unauthorized Access Attempts to Files (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor for unsuccessful attempts to access files. The parameters below are associated with system calls that control creation (creat), opening (open, openat) and truncation (truncate, ftruncate) of files. An audit log record will only be written if the user is a non-privileged user (auid > = 500), is not a Daemon event (auid=4294967295) and if the system call returned EACCES (permission denied to the file) or EPERM (some other permanent error associated with the specific system call). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "access."

criteria.comment: Collect Unsuccessful Unauthorized Access Attempts to Files (Scored)

metadata.title: Collect Use of Privileged Commands (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor privileged programs (thos that have the setuid and/or setgid bit set on execution) to determine if unprivileged users are running these commands.

metadata.title: Collect Successful File System Mounts (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor the use of the mount system call. The mount (and umount) system call controls the mounting and unmounting of file systems. The parameters below configure the system to create an audit record when the mount system call is used by a non-privileged user

metadata.title: Collect File Deletion Events by User (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor the use of system calls associated with the deletion or renaming of files and file attributes. This configuration statement sets up monitoring for the unlink (remove a file), unlinkat (remove a file attribute), rename (rename a file) and renameat (rename a file attribute) system calls and tags them with the identifier "delete".

criteria.comment: Collect File Deletion Events by User (Scored)

criterion.comment: Collect File Deletion Events by User (Scored)
Collect File Deletion Events by User (Scored)

metadata.title: Collect Changes to System Administration Scope (sudoers) (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor scope changes for system administrations. If the system has been properly configured to force system administrators to log in as themselves first and then use the sudo command to execute privileged commands, it is possible to monitor changes in scope. The file /etc/sudoers will be written to when the file or its attributes have changed. The audit records will be tagged with the identifier "scope."

criteria.comment: Collect Changes to System Administration Scope (sudoers) (Scored)

criterion.comment: Collect Changes to System Administration Scope (sudoers) (Scored)

metadata.title: Collect System Administrator Actions (sudolog) (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor the sudo log file. If the system has been properly configured to disable the use of the su command and force all administrators to have to log in first and then use sudo to execute privileged commands, then all administrator commands will be logged to /var/log/sudo.log. Any time a command is executed, an audit event will be triggered as the /var/log/sudo.log file will be opened for write and the executed administration command will be written to the log.

metadata.title: Collect Kernel Module Loading and Unloading (Scored)
metadata.description: Monitor the loading and unloading of kernel modules. The programs insmod (install a kernel module), rmmod (remove a kernel module), and modprobe (a more sophisticated program to load and unload modules, as well as some other features) control loading and unloading of modules. The init_module (load a module) and delete_module (delete a module) system calls control loading and unloading of modules. Any execution of the loading and unloading module programs and system calls will trigger an audit record with an identifier of "modules".

criteria.comment: Collect Kernel Module Loading and Unloading (Scored)

criterion.comment: Collect Kernel Module Loading and Unloading (Scored)
Collect Kernel Module Loading and Unloading (Scored)

metadata.title: Make the Audit Configuration Immutable (Scored)
metadata.description: Set system audit so that audit rules cannot be modified with auditctl. Setting the flag "-e 2" forces audit to be put in immutable mode. Audit changes can only be made on system reboot.

metadata.title: Install the rsyslog package (Scored)
metadata.description: The rsyslog package is a third party package that provides many enhancements to syslog, such as multi-threading, TCP communication, message filtering and data base support.

metadata.description: By default, rsyslog does not listen for log messages coming in from remote systems. The ModLoad tells rsyslog to load the imtcp.so module so it can listen over a network via TCP. The InputTCPServerRun option instructs rsyslogd to listen on the specified TCP port.

metadata.title: Configure logrotate (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The system includes the capability of rotating log files regularly to avoid filling up the system with logs or making the logs unmanageable large. The file /etc/logrotate.d/syslog is the configuration file used to rotate log files created by syslog or rsyslog.

The files in this directory cannot be manipulated by the crontab command, but are instead edited by system administrators using a text editor. The commands below restrict read/write and search access to user and group root, preventing regular users from accessing this directory.

metadata.title: Set User/Group Owner and Permission on /etc/cron.d (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/cron.d directory contains system cron jobs that need to run in a similar manner to the hourly, daily weekly and monthly jobs from /etc/crontab, but require more granular control as to when they run. The files in this directory cannot be manipulated by the crontab command, but are instead edited by system administrators using a text editor. The commands below restrict read/write and search access to user and group root, preventing regular users from accessing this directory.

criteria.comment: Set User/Group Owner and Permission on /etc/cron.d (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set User/Group Owner and Permission on /etc/cron.d (Scored)

metadata.title: Restrict at/cron to Authorized Users (Scored)
metadata.description: Configure /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow to allow specific users to use these services. If /etc/cron.allow or /etc/at.allow do not exist, then /etc/at.deny and /etc/cron.deny are checked. Any user not specifically defined in those files is allowed to use at and cron. By removing the files, only users in /etc/cron.allow and /etc/at.allow are allowed to use at and cron. Note that even though a given user is not listed in cron.allow, cron jobs can still be run as that user. The cron.allow file only controls administrative access to the crontab command for scheduling and modifying cron jobs.

metadata.title: Set SSH Protocol to 2 (Scored)
metadata.description: SSH supports two different and incompatible protocols: SSH1 and SSH2. SSH1 was the original protocol and was subject to security issues. SSH2 is more advanced and secure.

metadata.title: Set LogLevel to INFO (Scored)
metadata.description: The INFO parameter specifices that record login and logout activity will be logged.

metadata.title: Set Permissions on /etc/ssh/sshd_config (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/ssh/sshd_config file contains configuration specifications for sshd. The command below sets the owner and group of the file to root.

metadata.title: Disable SSH X11 Forwarding (Scored)
metadata.description: The X11Forwarding parameter provides the ability to tunnel X11 traffic through the connection to enable remote graphic connections.

metadata.title: Set SSH MaxAuthTries to 4 or Less (Scored)
metadata.description: The MaxAuthTries parameter specifies the maximum number of authentication attempts permitted per connection. When the login failure count reaches half the number, error messages will be written to the syslog file detailing the login failure.

criteria.comment: Set SSH MaxAuthTries to 4 or Less (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set SSH MaxAuthTries to 4 or Less (Scored)
Set SSH MaxAuthTries to 4 or Less (Scored)

metadata.title: Set SSH IgnoreRhosts to Yes (Scored)
metadata.description: The IgnoreRhosts parameter specifies that .rhosts and .shosts files will not be used in RhostsRSAAuthentication or HostbasedAuthentication.

metadata.title: Set SSH HostbasedAuthentication to No (Scored)
metadata.description: The HostbasedAuthentication parameter specifies if authentication is allowed through trusted hosts via the user of .rhosts, or /etc/hosts.equiv, along with successful public key client host authentication. This option only applies to SSH Protocol Version 2.

metadata.title: Disable SSH Root Login (Scored)
metadata.description: The PermitRootLogin parameter specifies if the root user can log in using ssh(1). The default is no.

metadata.title: Set SSH PermitEmptyPasswords to No (Scored)
metadata.description: The PermitEmptyPasswords parameter specifies if the server allows login to accounts with empty password strings.

metadata.title: Do Not Allow Users to Set Environment Options (Scored)
metadata.description: The PermitUserEnvironment option allows users to present environment options to the ssh daemon.

criteria.comment: Do Not Allow Users to Set Environment Options (Scored)

criterion.comment: Do Not Allow Users to Set Environment Options (Scored)

metadata.title: Use Only Approved Cipher in Counter Mode (Scored)
metadata.description: This variable limits the types of ciphers that SSH can use during communication.

criteria.comment: Use Only Approved Cipher in Counter Mode (Scored)

criterion.comment: Use Only Approved Cipher in Counter Mode (Scored)

metadata.title: Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Login (Scored)
metadata.description: The two options ClientAliveInterval and ClientAliveCountMax control the timeout of ssh sessions. When the ClientAliveInterval variable is set, ssh sessions that have no activity for the specified length of time are terminated. When the ClientAliveCountMax variable is set, sshd will send client alive messages at every ClientAliveInterval interval. When the number of consecutive client alive messages are sent with no response from the client, the ssh session is terminated. For example, if the ClientAliveInterval is set to 15 seconds and the ClientAliveCountMax is set to 3, the client ssh session will be terminated after 45 seconds of idle time.

criteria.comment: Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Login (Scored)

metadata.title: Set SSH Banner (Scored)
metadata.description: The Banner parameter specifies a file whose contents must be sent to the remote user before authentication is permitted. By default, no banner is displayed.

metadata.title: Set Password Creation Requirement Parameters Using pam_cracklib (Scored)
metadata.description: The pam_cracklib module checks of the strength of passwords. It performs checks such as making sure a password is not a dictionary word, it is a certain length, contains a mix of characters (e.g. alphabet, numeric, other) and more.

metadata.description: Lock out users after n unsuccessful consecutive login attempts. The first sets of changes are made to the PAM configuration file /etc/pam.d/login. The second set of changes are applied to the program specific PAM configuration file. The second set of changes must be applied to each program that will lock out users. Check the documentation for each secondary program for instructions on how to configure them to work with PAM. Set the lockout number to the policy in effect at your site.

metadata.title: Limit Password Reuse (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/security/opasswd file stores the users' old passwords and can be checked to ensure that users are not recycling recent passwords.

metadata.title: Restrict Access to the su Command (Scored)
metadata.description: The su command allows a user to run a command or shell as another user. The program has been superseded by sudo, which allows for more granular control over privileged access. Normally, the su command can be executed by any user. By uncommenting the pam_wheel.so statement in /etc/pam.d/su, the su command will only allow users in the wheel group to execute su.

criteria.comment: Restrict Access to the su Command (Scored)

criterion.comment: Restrict Access to the su Command (Scored)
Restrict Access to the su Command (Scored)

metadata.title: Set Password Expiration Days (Scored)
metadata.description: The PASS_MAX_DAYS parameter in /etc/login.defs allows an administrator to force passwords to expire once they reach a defined age. It is recommended that the PASS_MAX_DAYS parameter be set to less than or equal to 90 days.

metadata.title: Set Password Change Minimum Number of Days (Scored)
metadata.description: The PASS_MIN_DAYS parameter in /etc/login.defs allows an administrator to prevent users from changing their password until a minimum number of days have passed since the last time the user changed their password. It is recommended that PASS_MIN_DAYS parameter be set to 7 or more days.

criteria.comment: Set Password Change Minimum Number of Days (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set Password Change Minimum Number of Days (Scored)
Set Password Change Minimum Number of Days (Scored)

metadata.title: Set Password Expiring Warning Days (Scored)
metadata.description: The PASS_WARN_AGE parameter in /etc/login.defs allows an administrator to notify users that their password will expire in a defined number of days. It is recommended that the PASS_WARN_AGE parameter be set to 7 or more days.

metadata.title: Disable System Accounts (Scored)
metadata.description: There are a number of accounts provided with most distributions that are used to manage applications and are not intended to provide an interactive shell.

metadata.title: Set Default Group for root Account (Scored)
metadata.description: The usermod command can be used to specify which group the root user belongs to. This affects permissions of files that are created by the root user.

criteria.comment: Set Default Group for root Account (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set Default Group for root Account (Scored)

metadata.title: Set Default umask for Users (Scored)
metadata.description: The default umask determines the permissions of files created by users. The user creating the file has the discretion of making their files and directories readable by others via the chmod command. Users who wish to allow their files and directories to be readable by others by default may choose a different default umask by inserting the umask command into the standard shell configuration files (.profile, .bashrc, etc.) in their home directories.

metadata.title: Lock Inactive User Accounts (Scored)
metadata.description: User accounts that have been inactive for over a given period of time can be automatically disabled. It is recommended that accounts that are inactive for 35 or more days be disabled.

metadata.title: Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services (Scored)
metadata.description: The contents of the /etc/issue file are displayed prior to the login prompt on the system's console and serial devices, and also prior to logins via telnet. The contents of the /etc/motd file is generally displayed after all successful logins, no matter where the user is logging in from, but is thought to be less useful because it only provides notification to the user after the machine has been accessed.

criteria.comment: Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services (Scored)

criterion.comment: Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services (Scored)

Set Warning Banner for Standard Login Services (Scored)

metadata.title: Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (Scored)
metadata.description: Unix-based systems have typically displayed information about the OS release and patch level upon logging in to the system. This information can be useful to developers who are developing software for a particular OS platform.

criteria.comment: Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (Scored)

criterion.comment: Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (Scored)
Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (Scored)
Remove OS Information from Login Warning Banners (Scored)

metadata.title: Set Graphical Warning Banner (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Suse can use either the GNOME Display Manager or KDM for login session management. The remediation action for this item sets a warning message for GDM and KDM users before they log in.

metadata.title: Verify System File Permissions (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The RPM package manager has a number of useful options. One of these, the -V (or -verify) option, can be used to verify that system packages are correctly installed. The -V option can be used to verify a particular package or to verify all system packages (-Va). If no output is returned, the package is installed correctly.

metadata.title: Verify Permissions on /etc/passwd (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/passwd file contains user account information that is used by many system utilities and therefore must be readable for these utilities to operate.

metadata.title: Verify Permissions on /etc/shadow (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file is used to store the information about user accounts that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.

metadata.title: Verify Permissions on /etc/group (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/group file contains a list of all the valid groups defined in the system. The command below allows read/write access for root and read access for everyone else.

metadata.title: Verify User/Group Ownership on /etc/passwd (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/passwd file contains a list of all the valid userIDs defined in the system, but not the passwords. The command below sets the owner and group of the file to root.

metadata.title: Verify User/Group Ownership on /etc/shadow (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file contains the one-way cipher text passwords for each user defined in the /etc/passwd file. The command below sets the user and group ownership of the file to root.

metadata.title: Verify User/Group Ownership on /etc/group (Scored)
metadata.description: The /etc/group file contains a list of all the valid groups defined in the system. The command below allows read/write access for root and read access for everyone else.

metadata.title: Find World Writable Files (Not Scored)
metadata.description: Unix-based systems support variable settings to control access to files. World writable files are the least secure. See the chmod(2) man page for more information.

metadata.title: Find Un-owned Files and Directories (Scored)
metadata.description: Sometimes when administrators delete users from the password file they neglect to remove all files owned by those users from the system.

metadata.title: Find Un-grouped Files and Directories (Scored)
metadata.description: Sometimes when administrators delete users from the password file they neglect to remove all files owned by those users from the system.

metadata.title: Find SUID System Executables (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The owner of a file can set the file's permissions to run with the owner's or group's permissions, even if the user running the program is not the owner or a member of the group. The most common reason for a SUID program is to enable users to perform functions (such as changing their password) that require root privileges.

metadata.title: Find SGID System Executables (Not Scored)
metadata.description: The owner of a file can set the file's permissions to run with the owner's or group's permissions, even if the user running the program is not the owner or a member of the group. The most common reason for a SGID program is to enable users to perform functions (such as changing their password) that require root privileges.

metadata.title: Ensure Password Fields are Not Empty (Scored)
metadata.description: An account with an empty password field means that anybody may log in as that user without providing a password.

criteria.comment: Ensure Password Fields are Not Empty (Scored)

criterion.comment: Ensure Password Fields are Not Empty (Scored)

metadata.title: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/passwd File (Scored)
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

criteria.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/passwd File (Scored)

criterion.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/passwd File (Scored)

metadata.title: Verify No Legacy "+" Entries Exist in /etc/shadow File (Scored)
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

criteria.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/shadow File (Scored)

criterion.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/shadow File (Scored)

metadata.title: Verify No Legacy "+" Entries Exist in /etc/group File (Scored)
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

criteria.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/group File (Scored)

criterion.comment: Verify No Legacy + Entries Exist in /etc/group File (Scored)

metadata.title: Verify No UID 0 Accounts Exist Other Than root (Scored)
metadata.description: Any account with UID 0 has superuser privileges on the system.

criteria.comment: Verify No UID 0 Accounts Exist Other Than root (Scored)

criterion.comment: Verify No UID 0 Accounts Exist Other Than root (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure root PATH Integrity (Scored)
metadata.description: The root user can execute any command on the system and could be fooled into executing programs unemotionally if the PATH is not set correctly.

metadata.title: Check Permissions on User Home Directories (Scored)
metadata.description: While the system administrator can establish secure permissions for users' home directories, the users can easily override these.

criteria.comment: Check Permissions on User Home Directories (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check Permissions on User Home Directories (Scored)

metadata.title: Check User Dot File Permissions (Scored)
metadata.description: While the system administrator can establish secure permissions for users' "dot" files, the users can easily override these.

metadata.title: Check Permissions on User .netrc Files (Scored)
metadata.description: While the system administrator can establish secure permissions for users' .netrc files, the users can easily override these.

metadata.title: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)
metadata.description: While no .rhosts files are shipped by default, users can easily create them.

criteria.comment: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)

metadata.title: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)
metadata.description: While no .rhosts files are shipped by default, users can easily create them.

criteria.comment: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files (Scored)

metadata.title: Check That Users Are Assigned Valid Home Directories (Scored)
metadata.description: Users can be defined in /etc/passwd without a home directory or with a home directory does not actually exist.

criteria.comment: Check That Users Are Assigned Valid Home Directories (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check That Users Are Assigned Valid Home Directories (Scored)

metadata.title: Check User Home Directory Ownership (Scored)
metadata.description: The user home directory is space defined for the particular user to set local environment variables and to store personal files.

metadata.title: Check for Duplicate UIDs (Scored)
metadata.description: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate User ID (UID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the UID field.

metadata.title: Check for Duplicate GIDs (Scored)
metadata.description: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate Group ID (GID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the GID field.

metadata.title: Check for Duplicate User Names (Scored)
metadata.description: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate user name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the user name.

metadata.title: Check for Duplicate Group Names (Scored)
metadata.description: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate group name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the group name.

metadata.title: Check for Presence of User .netrc Files (Scored)
metadata.description: The .netrc file contains data for logging into a remote host for file transfers via FTP.

criteria.comment: Check for Presence of User .netrc Files (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check for Presence of User .netrc Files (Scored)

metadata.title: Check for Presence of User .forward Files (Scored)
metadata.description: The .forward file specifies an email address to forward the user's mail to.

criteria.comment: Check for Presence of User .forward Files (Scored)

criterion.comment: Check for Presence of User .forward Files (Scored)

metadata.title: Ensure shadow group is empty (Scored)
metadata.description: The shadow group allows system programs which require access the ability to read the /etc/shadow file. No users should be assigned to the shadow group.

ind-def:remotecommand_object.ind-def:cmd: df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -type d \( -perm -0002 -a ! -perm -1000 \) 2>/dev/null | head -n 100
if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then dmesg | grep NX; fi
grep "^[[:space:]]*restrict[[:space:]][[:space:]]*default[[:space:]][[:space:]]*" /etc/ntp.conf | grep "kod" | grep "nomodify" | grep "notrap" | grep "nopeer" | grep "noquery"

grep "^[[:space:]]*restrict[[:space:]][[:space:]]*-6[[:space:]][[:space:]]*default[[:space:]][[:space:]]*" /etc/ntp.conf | grep "kod" | grep "nomodify" | grep "notrap" | grep "nopeer" | grep "noquery"
grep time-change /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep adjtimex | grep settimeofday | grep stime
grep time-change /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep clock_settime

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep time-change /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep adjtimex | grep settimeofday` ;fi;
if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep time-change /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep clock_settime` ;fi;
grep system-locale /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep exit,always | grep "arch=b32" | grep sethostname | grep setdomainname

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep system-locale /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep exit,always | grep "arch=b64" | grep sethostname | grep setdomainname` ;fi;
grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep chmod | grep fchmod | grep fchmodat | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"
grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep chown | grep fchown | grep fchownat | grep lchown | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"

grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep setxattr | grep lsetxattr | grep fsetxattr | grep removexattr | grep lremovexattr | grep fremovexattr | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep chmod | grep fchmod | grep fchmodat | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep chown | grep fchown | grep fchownat | grep lchown | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep perm_mod /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep setxattr | grep lsetxattr | grep fsetxattr | grep removexattr | grep lremovexattr | grep fremovexattr | grep "auid>=500" | grep -F "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

grep access /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep creat | grep open | grep openat | grep truncate | grep ftruncate | grep exit=-EACCES | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"

grep access /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep creat | grep open | grep openat | grep truncate | grep ftruncate | grep exit=-EPERM | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep access /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep creat | grep open | grep openat | grep truncate | grep ftruncate | grep "exit=-EACCES" | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep access /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep creat | grep open | grep openat | grep truncate | grep ftruncate | grep "exit=-EPERM" | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

for loopdir in /bin /sbin;do for loop in `find $loopdir -xdev \( -perm -4000 -o -perm -2000 \) -type f`; do if [ "`grep $loop /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null`" = "" ]; then echo $loop;fi;done;done;
grep mounts /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep mount | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep mounts /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep mount | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;
grep delete /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b32" | grep unlink | grep unlinkat | grep rename | grep renameat | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep delete /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep unlink | grep unlinkat | grep rename | grep renameat | grep "auid>=500" | grep "auid!=4294967295"` ;fi;

if [ "`uname -a | grep 'i386'`" != "" ]; then echo "arch32" ;else echo `grep modules /etc/audit/audit.rules 2>/dev/null | grep always,exit | grep "arch=b64" | grep init_module | grep delete_module` ;fi;
for loop in `find /var/log -type f`; do if [ "`grep $loop /etc/rsyslog.conf 2>/dev/null`" != "" ]; then if [ "`stat -c "%a %u %g" $loop | egrep ".00 0 0"`" = "" ]; then echo $loop; fi; fi; done;
grep "Ciphers" /etc/ssh/sshd_config | grep aes128-ctr | grep aes192-ctr | grep aes256-ctr
file=`grep -E '^[[:space:]]*Banner[[:space:]]+[^[:space:]]+[[:space:]]*$' /etc/ssh/sshd_config 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $2}'`; if [ "$file" != "" ] && [ -f "$file" ]; then echo $file; fi
for user in `awk -F: '($3 >= 500) {print $1}' /etc/passwd`; do chage --list $user | grep Maximum | awk -v user="$user" '{if($2 > 90) print user}'; done
for user in `awk -F: '($3 >= 500) {print $1}' /etc/passwd`; do chage --list $user | grep Minimum | awk -v user="$user" '{if($2 < 7) print user}'; done
for user in `awk -F: '($3 >= 500) {print $1}' /etc/passwd`; do chage --list $user | grep Warning | awk -v user="$user" '{if($2 < 7) print user}'; done
rpm -q xorg-x11 | grep -E 'xorg-x11-' >/dev/null && { grep GreetString /usr/share/kde4/config/kdm/kdmrc 2>/dev/null; echo -n; } || echo "yes"
rpm -q xorg-x11 | grep -E 'xorg-x11-' >/dev/null && { gconftool-2 --get /apps/gdm/simple-greeter/banner_message_text 2>/dev/null; echo -n; } || echo "yes"
df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -type f -perm -0002 -print | head -n 100
df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -nouser -ls | head -n 100
df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -nogroup -ls | head -n 100
df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -type f -perm -4000 -print | head -n 100
df --local -P | awk {'if (NR!=1) print $6'} | xargs -I '{}' find '{}' -xdev -type f -perm -2000 -print | head -n 100
/bin/cat /etc/shadow | /bin/awk -F: '($2 == "" ) { print $1 " does not have a password "}'

find `cat /etc/passwd | egrep -v '(root|sync|halt|shutdown)' | awk -F: '($7 != "/sbin/nologin") { print $6 }'` -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '\.*' -prune \( -perm /g=w -o -perm /o=w \) 2>/dev/null | head -n 100

find `cat /etc/passwd | egrep -v '(root|sync|halt|shutdown)' | awk -F: '($7 != "/sbin/nologin") { print $6 }'` -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '\.netrc' -prune \( -perm /g=rwx -o -perm /o=rwx \) 2>/dev/null | head -n 100
find `cat /etc/passwd | egrep -v '(root|sync|halt|shutdown)' | awk -F: '($7 != "/sbin/nologin") { print $6 }'` -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '\.rhosts' 2>/dev/null | head -n 100

for i in $(cut -s -d: -f4 /etc/passwd | sort -u ); do grep -q -P "^.*?:[^:]*:$i:" /etc/group; if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "Group $i is referenced by /etc/passwd but does not exist in /etc/group"; fi; done

cat /etc/passwd | awk -F: '{ print $1 " " $3 " " $6 }' | while read user uid dir; do if [ $uid -ge 500 -a ! -d "$dir" -a $user != "nfsnobody" ]; then echo "The home directory ($dir) of user $user does not exist."; fi; done

cat /etc/passwd | awk -F: '{ print $1 " " $3 " " $6 }' | while read user uid dir; do if [ $uid -ge 500 -a -d "$dir" -a $user != "nfsnobody" ]; then owner=$(stat -L -c "%U" "$dir"); if [ "$owner" != "$user" ]; then echo "The home directory ($dir) of user $user is owned by $owner."; fi; fi; done
for u in `cut -d: -f3 /etc/passwd`; do test `egrep "^\w+:\w+:$u:" /etc/passwd|wc -l` -gt 1 && egrep "^\w+:\w+:$u:" /etc/passwd; done
for u in `cut -d: -f3 /etc/group`; do test `egrep "^\w+:\w+:$u:" /etc/group|wc -l` -gt 1 && egrep "^\w+:\w+:$u:" /etc/group; done
for u in `cut -d: -f1 /etc/passwd`; do test `egrep "^$u+:" /etc/passwd|wc -l` -gt 1 && egrep "^$u:" /etc/passwd; done
for u in `cut -d: -f1 /etc/group`; do test `egrep "^$u+:" /etc/group|wc -l` -gt 1 && egrep "^$u:" /etc/group; done
